articles.headline: Economic Shifts in U.S. and China Batter Markets
articles.snippet: With China’s rise and the Federal Reserve’s economic action both in retreat, investors have been heading for the exits in markets as far removed as Buenos Aires, Istanbul and Beijing, with effects spilling over into the rest of the world.
articles.abstract: With China’s rise and the Federal Reserve’s economic action both in retreat, investors have been heading for the exits in markets as far removed as Buenos Aires, Istanbul and Beijing, with effects spilling over into the rest of the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:20 p.m. | The ascent of developing countries over the last decade has been fueled by two global trends: the steady rise of China and the willingness of the Federal Reserve to stimulate the economy.

articles.headline: In Russia, Couriers Halt Parcel Delivery
articles.snippet: Because of new customs restrictions, several major express delivery services have stopped delivering packages to individual clients.
articles.abstract: Because of new customs restrictions, several major express delivery services have stopped delivering packages to individual clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia has never been an easy country in which to deliver packages because of its vast size. The government just made it a lot harder for anyone buying things online.

articles.headline: Big Raise for JPMorgan’s Dimon Despite a Rough Year
articles.snippet: The bank’s chief executive will receive $20 million in compensation for 2013, a raise of 74 percent over the previous year, despite a series of bruising legal setbacks.
articles.abstract: The bank’s chief executive will receive $20 million in compensation for 2013, a raise of 74 percent over the previous year, despite a series of bruising legal setbacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:09 p.m. | JPMorgan Chase, after a year marred by scandal and stiff regulatory penalties, has decided to award its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, $20 million in compensation for 2013, an amount that will further inflame the debate over the accountability of senior bank executives.

articles.headline: A Lawyer and Partner, and Also Bankrupt
articles.snippet: Gregory M. Owens is an extreme but vivid illustration of the economic factors roiling the legal profession.
articles.abstract: Gregory M. Owens is an extreme but vivid illustration of the economic factors roiling the legal profession.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anyone who wonders why law school applications are plunging and there’s widespread malaise in many big law firms might consider the case of Gregory M. Owens.

articles.headline: Old Democratic Name (Nunn) Stakes Bid on Shifting Georgia
articles.snippet: Michelle Nunn, the daughter of a former senator, is running for the Senate in a campaign that is testing whether the state’s shifting demographics can send a Democrat to Washington.
articles.abstract: Michelle Nunn, the daughter of a former senator, is running for the Senate in a campaign that is testing whether the state’s shifting demographics can send a Democrat to Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: PERRY, Ga. — As a little girl, Michelle Nunn clutched her father’s hand as they strolled the pecan groves of the family’s 2,400-acre farm, a moment captured in a black-and-white photograph that Sam Nunn used to help win election to the Senate. It hangs in a Sam Nunn exhibit in this small city south of Macon, where the main thoroughfare is Sam Nunn Boulevard.

articles.headline: Flood Ebbs, Insurance Woes Don’t
articles.snippet: The deadline to submit final flood insurance claims is approaching. Some tips to avoid the minefields.
articles.abstract: The deadline to submit final flood insurance claims is approaching. Some tips to avoid the minefields.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mayor of Hoboken, N.J., isn’t the only one complaining that her Hurricane Sandy relief money has been held hostage.

articles.headline: Judge Orders Hospital to Remove Pregnant Woman From Life Support
articles.snippet: Doctors had cited a Texas law that prevents them from withdrawing or withholding “life-sustaining treatment” from a pregnant patient.
articles.abstract: Doctors had cited a Texas law that prevents them from withdrawing or withholding “life-sustaining treatment” from a pregnant patient.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — A Texas judge ruled Friday that a Fort Worth hospital may not keep a brain-dead pregnant woman on life support against her family’s wishes, and ordered doctors to take her off the machines by 5 p.m. on Monday.

articles.headline: The Elders of Organic Farming
articles.snippet: For nearly a week, two dozen pioneers of sustainable agriculture from the United States and Canada shared decades’ worth of stories, secrets and anxieties.
articles.abstract: For nearly a week, two dozen pioneers of sustainable agriculture from the United States and Canada shared decades’ worth of stories, secrets and anxieties.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIG SUR, Calif. — Among the sleek guests who meditate and do Downward Facing Dog here at the Esalen Institute, the farmers appeared to be out of place. They wore baggy jeans, suspenders and work boots and had long ago let their hair go gray.

articles.headline: Star Envoy’s Frankness Puts Kennedy Mystique to Test in Japan
articles.snippet: Japan swooned when Caroline Kennedy arrived as the United States’ ambassador, but she has surprised her hosts with her frankness on delicate issues, including a controversial dolphin hunt.
articles.abstract: Japan swooned when Caroline Kennedy arrived as the United States’ ambassador, but she has surprised her hosts with her frankness on delicate issues, including a controversial dolphin hunt.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan went into a collective swoon two months ago when Caroline Kennedy arrived as the United States’ ambassador. The appointment of someone with such celebrity appeal — who offered a living link to a golden age when America was still reassuringly strong and confident — appeared to be proof that Washington was finally giving Japan the embrace it craved.

articles.headline: The Tale of a House, and an Entire Market
articles.snippet: The history of 12204 Backus Drive in Bowie, Md., is in many ways the history of the American housing market over the last two decades.
articles.abstract: The history of 12204 Backus Drive in Bowie, Md., is in many ways the history of the American housing market over the last two decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1990, almost a million houses were built in the United States. One of them, at 12204 Backus Drive in Bowie, Md., was a four-bedroom colonial with a bay window. The average home price that year was $150,000; this house, in a desirable middle-class suburb of Washington, sold for $227,140.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Catherine Rampell

articles.headline: Asking Banks to Reveal Where Their High Rollers Are
articles.snippet: The New York State comptroller wants banks to take an inventory of their risk-taking employees.
articles.abstract: The New York State comptroller wants banks to take an inventory of their risk-taking employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: For investors who held stakes in large and complex financial institutions in 2008, the perils lurking inside these behemoths came as a costly shock.

articles.headline: The Gadfly of Greenwich Real Estate
articles.snippet: Amid dozens of unsold mega-mansions, a real estate agent sees a glut of greed.
articles.abstract: Amid dozens of unsold mega-mansions, a real estate agent sees a glut of greed.
articles.lead_paragraph: As he drives his white pickup truck past the manors that crowd the hills and meadows along Round Hill Road in Greenwich, Conn. — a town that has long signified what it means to be rich in America — Christopher Fountain snorts.

articles.headline: Opposition Says No to Ukraine on Power Share
articles.snippet: President Viktor F. Yanukovych offered to install opposition leaders in top government posts, but they swiftly rebuffed the offer, to the delight of thousands of protesters on the street.
articles.abstract: President Viktor F. Yanukovych offered to install opposition leaders in top government posts, but they swiftly rebuffed the offer, to the delight of thousands of protesters on the street.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — In a striking concession aimed at defusing Ukraine’s civil uprising and preserving his own grip on power, President Viktor F. Yanukovych on Saturday offered to install opposition leaders in top posts in a reshaped government, but they swiftly rebuffed the offer to the delight of thousands of protesters on the street craving a fuller victory in the days ahead.

articles.headline: Rand Paul’s Mixed Inheritance
articles.snippet: As Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky tries to broaden his appeal, he is also trying to take libertarianism, an ideology long on the fringes of American politics, into the mainstream.
articles.abstract: As Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky tries to broaden his appeal, he is also trying to take libertarianism, an ideology long on the fringes of American politics, into the mainstream.
articles.lead_paragraph: The libertarian faithful — antitax activists and war protesters, John Birch Society members and a smattering of “truthers” who suspect the government’s hand in the 2001 terrorist attacks — gathered last September, eager to see the rising star of their movement.
articles.byline: By Sam Tanenhaus and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Obama Pursuing a Modest Agenda in State of Union
articles.snippet: President Obama has come to feel the constraints on his power acutely. He is set to announce executive actions on the environment and the economy that do not need the approval of Congress.
articles.abstract: President Obama has come to feel the constraints on his power acutely. He is set to announce executive actions on the environment and the economy that do not need the approval of Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — His ambitions in check and his eye on the calendar, President Obama intends to use his State of the Union address to put a difficult year behind him and reassert command before the capital is consumed with election-year politics.

articles.headline: Accidents Surge as Oil Industry Takes the Train
articles.snippet: Residents of Casselton, N.D., are concerned about the crude-oil convoys that roll through their town, as what was once a stopgap becomes commonplace and safety standards lag.
articles.abstract: Residents of Casselton, N.D., are concerned about the crude-oil convoys that roll through their town, as what was once a stopgap becomes commonplace and safety standards lag.
articles.lead_paragraph: CASSELTON, N.D. — Kerry’s Kitchen is where Casselton residents gather for gossip and comfort food, especially the caramel rolls baked fresh every morning. But a fiery rail accident last month only a half mile down the tracks, which prompted residents to evacuate the town, has shattered this calm, along with people’s confidence in the crude-oil convoys that rumble past Kerry’s seven times a day.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Holocaust Told in One Word, 6 Million Times
articles.snippet: The book “And Every Single One Was Someone” — meant as a kind of coffee-table monument or conversation starter — consists of the single word “Jew,” printed six million times.
articles.abstract: The book “And Every Single One Was Someone” — meant as a kind of coffee-table monument or conversation starter — consists of the single word “Jew,” printed six million times.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — There is no plot to speak of, and the characters are woefully undeveloped. On the upside, it can be a quick read — especially considering its 1,250 pages.

articles.headline: Ezra Klein Is Joining Vox Media as Web Journalism Asserts Itself
articles.snippet: Mr. Klein’s departure from The Washington Post to Vox Media is just one more example of how digital publishing offers its own thing, not an additional platform for established news companies.
articles.abstract: Mr. Klein’s departure from The Washington Post to Vox Media is just one more example of how digital publishing offers its own thing, not an additional platform for established news companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a week of speculation, it turns out that Ezra Klein, the prolific creator of The Washington Post’s Wonkblog, will be going to Vox Media, the online home of SB Nation, a sports site, and The Verge, a fast-growing technology site.

articles.headline: Chairwoman of Universal Expands Her Portfolio
articles.snippet: NBCUniversal announced it extended the contract of Donna Langley, chairwoman of Universal Pictures, through 2017 and handed her oversight of worldwide marketing and overseas production.
articles.abstract: NBCUniversal announced it extended the contract of Donna Langley, chairwoman of Universal Pictures, through 2017 and handed her oversight of worldwide marketing and overseas production.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. — A drained Donna Langley, chairwoman of Universal Pictures, sat down for lunch in the studio’s executive dining room here last month and let loose a dramatic sigh. Who could blame her?

articles.headline: Cannabis Legal, Localities Begin to Just Say No
articles.snippet: Local resistance to legal marijuana signals a larger fight over whether it will be a national industry or a patchwork system.
articles.abstract: Local resistance to legal marijuana signals a larger fight over whether it will be a national industry or a patchwork system.
articles.lead_paragraph: YAKIMA, Wash. — The momentum toward legalized marijuana might seem like an inevitable tide, with states from Florida to New York considering easing laws for medical use, and a full-blown recreational industry rapidly emerging in Colorado and here in Washington State.

articles.headline: Afghanistan Exit Is Seen as Peril to C.I.A. Drone Mission
articles.snippet: American intelligence agencies are concerned that they could lose their air bases used for drone strikes if a final security deal cannot be struck with the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai.
articles.abstract: American intelligence agencies are concerned that they could lose their air bases used for drone strikes if a final security deal cannot be struck with the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The risk that President Obama may be forced to pull all American troops out of Afghanistan by the end of the year has set off concerns inside the American intelligence agencies that they could lose their air bases used for drone strikes against Al Qaeda in Pakistan and for responding to a nuclear crisis in the region.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: 2014 Elections Likely to Keep Capital’s Split
articles.snippet: A review of competitive congressional contests suggests that Republicans will hold on to the House, while Senate Democrats will almost certainly see their majority narrowed.
articles.abstract: A review of competitive congressional contests suggests that Republicans will hold on to the House, while Senate Democrats will almost certainly see their majority narrowed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the 2014 political landscape becoming more defined, it is increasingly likely that the midterm elections in November will maintain divided government in the capital for the final two years of President Obama’s second term, with the chief unknown being exactly how divided it will be.

articles.headline: Rough Patch for Uber Service’s Challenge to Taxis
articles.snippet: Uber, the hot start-up whose software allows anyone with a smartphone to get a cab ride, is suddenly facing trouble.
articles.abstract: Uber, the hot start-up whose software allows anyone with a smartphone to get a cab ride, is suddenly facing trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It’s Travis Kalanick versus the world, and recently the world seems to be winning.

articles.headline: In South Korea, Spam Is the Stuff Gifts Are Made Of
articles.snippet: With the Korean War, the gelatinous meat began an unlikely journey to South Korea, where it is now so much a part of culinary life that many people have no idea of its origins.
articles.abstract: With the Korean War, the gelatinous meat began an unlikely journey to South Korea, where it is now so much a part of culinary life that many people have no idea of its origins.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — As the Lunar New Year holiday approaches, Seoul’s increasingly well-heeled residents are scouring store shelves for tastefully wrapped boxes of culinary specialties. Among their favorite choices: imported wines, choice cuts of beef, rare herbal teas. And Spam.

articles.headline: Justice Department Inquiry Takes Aim at Banks’ Business With Payday Lenders
articles.snippet: Federal prosecutors are scrutinizing whether banks have allowed businesses to siphon billions of dollars from consumers’ accounts.
articles.abstract: Federal prosecutors are scrutinizing whether banks have allowed businesses to siphon billions of dollars from consumers’ accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are trying to thwart the easy access that predatory lenders and dubious online merchants have to Americans’ bank accounts by going after banks that fail to meet their obligations as gatekeepers to the United States financial system.

articles.headline: Proposal to Raise Tip Wages Resisted
articles.snippet: As some Democrats push to raise the minimum wage, they are also backing increases to the minimum wage for workers who earn tips, but the restaurant industry is fiercely opposed to a mandated increase.
articles.abstract: As some Democrats push to raise the minimum wage, they are also backing increases to the minimum wage for workers who earn tips, but the restaurant industry is fiercely opposed to a mandated increase.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly 50 years ago, federal law created a lower minimum wage for workers who receive tips. Congress decreed that it could not be less than 50 percent of the federal minimum wage.

articles.headline: Egypt’s Ruler Eyes Riskier Role: The Presidency
articles.snippet: Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, who ousted Egypt’s first freely elected president, Mohamed Morsi, said he was yielding to the will of the people in taking the first formal step to run for the office himself.
articles.abstract: Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, who ousted Egypt’s first freely elected president, Mohamed Morsi, said he was yielding to the will of the people in taking the first formal step to run for the office himself.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — When Egypt’s first freely elected president, Mohamed Morsi, named Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi defense minister, the officer pledged to keep the military out of politics and make way for civilian democracy.
